title: In Futurity, Someone Prophetic Sees
material: In Futurity, Someone Prophetic Sees Nostradamus never predicted that people would remember him 500 years later, but his reputation for accurate prophecies has nonetheless flourished for centuries. Discuss with your team: why do people want to know their future in advance? Would it benefit them if they did? If someone offered you the opportunity to read a biography of your life, would you? Some poets have also taken a swing at predicting the future. Consider the selections below, then discuss with your team: how seriously were they intended to tell the future? Is poetry (with its often murky meanings) the perfect vehicle for prophecy? Horace | “Ode I. 11” (23 BCE) William Butler Yeats | “The Second Coming” (1919) Robert Frost | “Fire and Ice” (1920) Emily Dickinson | “The Future—never spoke” (1921) Anthropologists believe that this sort of divination is a practice as old as Neolithic humans. Look briefly (no rabbit holes, please) into the following ancient divination techniques, then discuss with your team: which are still practiced today, and, if they seem hard to believe now, why do you think so many people once believed in them? comparative horoscopy | haruspicy | ornithomancy | alectryomancy pyro-osteomancy | oneiromancy | bibliomancy | hydromancy astragalomancy | scyphomancy | astrology Firefighter, astronaut, investment banker—diviner of the future? If you’re thinking about future careers, consider a career in thinking about the future. Explore the following future-telling occupations, then discuss with your team: should governments regulate this industry, and, if so, how? palmistry | physiognomy | ceromancy | tasseography | cartomancy fortune teller | oracle | soothsayer | shaman | witch | clairvoyant Ifá | Jyotish | I Ching | Bazi | Jiaobei | omikuji | Ouija | crystal ball fortune cookies | horoscopes Not all fortune tellers are mystics. Michio Kaku is an award-winning theoretical physicist whose side business is predicting the future in books like Physics of the Future and The Future of Humanity. Explore some of his predictions, then discuss with your team: which of his predictions do you find too alarmist? Which ones do you most look forward to? While those predicting the future cast their gaze forward to tomorrow and the days after, some artists cast their gaze (and occasionally their glaze) toward those making the predictions. Review the following artworks with your team, then discuss with your team: what are they trying to tell us? Art Caravaggio | The Fortune Teller (c. 1595) Georges de la Tour | The Fortune Teller (c. 1630) Michael Vrubel | The Fortune Teller (1895) Julio Romero de Torres | The Fortune Teller (1922) Helena Sofia Schjerfbeck | The Fortune Teller (Woman in a Yellow Dress) (1926) Jose Luis Cuevas | Dreams of Rasputin (1968) Music Georges Bizet | “Trio des Cartes” (1875) Carl Orff | “O Fortuna” (1935) Benny Spellman | “Fortune Teller” (1962) Al Stewart | “Nostradamus” (1973) Suzanne Vega | “Predictions” (1990) Certain methods of divination seem more reliable than they are. Explore the following examples and terms, then discuss with your team: why is divination enjoying a resurgence amongst young people today? Is the future trending? Barnum effect | Pygmalion effect | cold reading | confirmation bias | self-fulfilling prophecy Did you freely choose to read this bullet, or were you always bound to find yourself puzzling over it at this very moment? Explore the age-old debate between those who believe we have free will and those who believe we live in a deterministic universe, then discuss with your team: how much does it matter whether we are making choices for ourselves? Is it possible that some people have more free will than others? And, if criminals are not really choosing to be criminals, should they still be punished? Be sure to learn the differences between genetic, biological, and other forms of determinism. Ted Chiang | “What's expected of us” (2005) C. Robert Cargill | Excerpts from Sea of Rust (2007) Sam Hughes | “I don't know, Timmy, being God Is a big responsibility” (2007) Not all methods of foretelling the future are rooted in superstition or ritual; some stem from long-term observations and lived experiences. For example, the Chinese agricultural calendar is based on centuries observing the weather and the movement of celestial bodies. The result is a calendar that reliably predicts the movements of the sun and moon, ocean tides, astronomical events, and the turning of the seasons—one still referenced by farmers today. Research the following and explore with your team: are there any other reliable not-quite scientific methods of predicting the future that merit continued study? Aztec agricultural calendar | Mayan cyclical calendars | zodiac | solar terms computus | saros | Metonic cycle | Antikythera mechanism Your weather app predicts a warm and dry afternoon; you wear a summer dress and you wind up drenched by an unexpected afternoon rainstorm. Research how meteorologists make weather forecasts and explore with your team: how far ahead in time is a weather forecast useful? How might AI prediction models change the field of meteorology? Be sure to also learn the difference between weather and climate models, and if they are still accurate in face of a changing climate. A butterfly flaps its wings and a hurricane (eventually) pops to life on the other side of the world. Small changes can have large impacts that may not be as random (or unpredictable) as they seem. Explore the field of chaos theory, which attempts to understand how complex systems are built up from simple parts, then discuss with your team: are there examples of such systems in society, and can they help us tell the future? Be sure to explore the following terms: emergence | self-organization | de-centralization | feedback | determinism chaotic systems | sensitivity | flocking model | three-body problem | fractals randomness | parameters | stable vs. unstable equilibria “Ripped jeans will be back in fashion in 20 years”, says one pundit. “We’ve been in a decade-long bull market, but just you wait for the bear market”, says another. Research the following popular “cycles” in public discourse today and explore with your team: what do they purport to predict, and how accurate are their predictions? Can a popular “cycle” ever become a scientific model? fashion cycle | nostalgia cycle | news cycle | business cycle market cycle | Moore’s law | Eroom’s law | platform decay bathtub curve of electronics | nomadic war machine

additional-material.name: Ode I. 11
additional-material.text:
"Ode I. 11," a poem by Horace, reflects on the uncertainty of fate and the importance of living in the present. The speaker addresses Leucon, emphasizing that neither of them can know what the future holds. This theme of uncertainty is underscored by the advice to refrain from seeking answers through divination methods, such as reading tea leaves or palms. Instead, the speaker advocates for patience and acceptance of whatever may come, suggesting that the future is beyond anyone's control.

The poem conveys a sense of urgency regarding the passage of time, as it notes that life is fleeting and unpredictable. The imagery of winter and the pounding of the Tuscan Sea against the rocks evokes a natural backdrop that mirrors the poem's contemplative tone. The speaker encourages Leucon to take action in the present—specifically, to "cut your vines" and let go of hope, which implies a need to focus on immediate responsibilities rather than future aspirations.

Horace's use of direct address creates an intimate dialogue, inviting readers to reflect on their own lives and the inevitability of time's progression. The poem's philosophical underpinnings resonate with themes of mortality and the human condition, suggesting that clinging to hope for the future may lead to disappointment. By urging a focus on the present, Horace aligns with Stoic principles, advocating for a life lived with wisdom and acceptance.

Ultimately, "Ode I. 11" serves as a meditation on the transient nature of existence and the importance of embracing the present moment. The poem's timeless message encourages readers to find meaning in their current experiences rather than being preoccupied with the uncertainties of what lies ahead.

additional-material.name: The Second Coming
additional-material.text:
"The Second Coming," a poem by William Butler Yeats, explores themes of chaos, transformation, and the cyclical nature of history. Written in the aftermath of World War I, the poem reflects Yeats's apprehension about the state of the world, characterized by a breakdown of social order and moral decay. The opening lines depict a world in disarray, where the falcon cannot hear the falconer, symbolizing a loss of control and the emergence of anarchy. This sense of disorder is further emphasized by the imagery of a "blood-dimmed tide" and the drowning of innocence, suggesting a profound societal crisis.

Yeats introduces the concept of the "Second Coming," a biblical reference that implies a significant, transformative event is imminent. The poem's imagery shifts to a vision from "Spiritus Mundi," where a monstrous figure with a lion's body and a man's head emerges from the desert. This creature, described as having a "gaze blank and pitiless as the sun," embodies the fear of an impending apocalypse and the birth of a new, potentially malevolent force. The juxtaposition of this figure against the backdrop of a world in turmoil raises questions about the nature of change and the potential for destruction inherent in new beginnings.

The poem's structure, with its rhythmic and repetitive qualities, enhances the sense of inevitability surrounding the events described. Yeats's use of stark and vivid imagery serves to evoke a visceral reaction from the reader, compelling them to confront the unsettling realities of their time. The closing lines, which ponder the arrival of this "rough beast" slouching towards Bethlehem, encapsulate the tension between hope and despair, suggesting that what is to come may not be redemptive but rather a harbinger of further chaos.

Overall, "The Second Coming" serves as a powerful commentary on the cyclical nature of history and the potential for upheaval in times of crisis. Yeats's exploration of these themes resonates with contemporary audiences, prompting reflection on the fragility of civilization and the forces that shape human destiny. The poem remains a poignant reminder of the complexities of change and the duality of creation and destruction inherent in the human experience.

additional-material.name: Fire and Ice
additional-material.text:
"Fire and Ice," a poem by Robert Frost, explores the themes of desire and hatred as potential forces for destruction. The poem opens with a contemplation of how the world might end, presenting two contrasting elements: fire, symbolizing desire, and ice, representing hate. The speaker expresses a preference for fire, suggesting that their experiences with desire align with the notion that it could lead to the world's demise. However, the speaker acknowledges that ice, or hatred, is equally capable of causing destruction.

Frost's use of simple yet evocative language allows for a profound exploration of human emotions. The poem's brevity and structure, consisting of nine lines, contribute to its impact, as it succinctly encapsulates complex ideas. The speaker's assertion that they "hold with those who favor fire" indicates a personal connection to desire, while the subsequent reflection on ice introduces a more universal perspective on the destructive potential of hate.

The poem raises questions about the nature of human emotions and their consequences. By juxtaposing fire and ice, Frost invites readers to consider the duality of passion and apathy, suggesting that both can lead to catastrophic outcomes. The imagery of fire and ice serves as a metaphor for the extremes of human experience, emphasizing that both desire and hatred can be equally potent in their capacity to bring about destruction.

Ultimately, "Fire and Ice" reflects on the inevitability of conflict and the human condition. The poem's implications extend beyond its immediate themes, prompting readers to reflect on their own emotions and the broader societal impacts of desire and hatred. Frost's work remains relevant, as it encapsulates timeless truths about the complexities of human nature and the forces that drive us toward destruction.

additional-material.name: The Future—never spoke
additional-material.text:
Emily Dickinson's poem "The Future—never spoke" explores the enigmatic nature of the future and its relationship with human understanding. The poem begins with the assertion that the future remains silent, refusing to communicate or reveal any information about what is to come. This silence is likened to that of a "Dumb" entity, emphasizing the idea that the future does not provide any signs or syllables that might hint at its contents. This lack of communication creates a sense of uncertainty and anticipation regarding future events.

The poem further elaborates on the concept that the future only presents itself when the time is right, described as "when the News be ripe." This suggests that the future's revelations are contingent upon specific moments, which may arrive unexpectedly. Dickinson introduces the idea of "Forestalling Preparation," indicating that the future can disrupt plans and expectations, forcing individuals to confront it in real-time rather than through foresight. The notion of escape or substitution implies that people may seek ways to avoid or alter their encounters with the future, highlighting a tension between human agency and the inevitability of fate.

Dickinson also reflects on the indifferent nature of the future, portraying it as a force that executes the decrees of fate without regard for individual desires or preparations. The phrase "The Dower—as the Doom" suggests a duality in the future's gifts and challenges, where what is bestowed can also lead to one's downfall. This duality reinforces the complexity of the future as both a promise and a threat, encapsulating the human experience of navigating uncertainty.

Ultimately, the poem presents the future as an inscrutable entity that operates beyond human comprehension and control. Dickinson's exploration of this theme invites readers to contemplate their relationship with time, fate, and the unknown, emphasizing the profound impact of the future on human existence. The poem's rich imagery and philosophical depth encourage reflection on how individuals prepare for and respond to the uncertainties that lie ahead.

additional-material.name: Neolithic humans
additional-material.text:
The article on oracle bones from the Shang Dynasty provides a comprehensive overview of their significance in ancient Chinese culture, particularly in the context of divination practices. Oracle bones, primarily made from the shoulder blades of oxen or the plastrons of turtles, were used during the Shang Dynasty (c. 1600–1046 BCE) for divination purposes. The process involved inscribing questions onto the bones, which were then subjected to heat until they cracked. The patterns of these cracks were interpreted by diviners to provide answers or guidance on various matters, including agriculture, warfare, and royal affairs.

The article emphasizes the dual role of oracle bones as both practical tools for divination and as historical artifacts that offer insights into the Shang Dynasty's social, political, and religious life. The inscriptions on the bones are among the earliest forms of Chinese writing, showcasing the development of written language in China. This writing system not only facilitated communication but also played a crucial role in the administration of the state, as it was used to record events and decisions made by the ruling elite.

Moreover, the article discusses the broader implications of oracle bones in understanding the Shang Dynasty's belief systems. The reliance on divination reflects a worldview that intertwined the spiritual and the material, suggesting that the Shang people sought to understand and influence their environment through communication with ancestral spirits and deities. This practice underscores the importance of ritual and the supernatural in governance and daily life during this period.

In conclusion, the oracle bones serve as a vital link to understanding the Shang Dynasty's culture, providing evidence of early Chinese writing, religious practices, and the socio-political structure of the time. Their study not only enriches the historical narrative of ancient China but also highlights the complexities of human belief and the quest for knowledge in the face of uncertainty.

additional-material.name: some of his predictions
additional-material.text:
The article profiles theoretical physicist and futurist Michio Kaku, highlighting his scientific credibility and his ability to translate complex research into predictions about humanity’s future. A longtime professor and pioneer in string field theory, Kaku has sought to unify the laws of the universe through a “theory of everything.” His standing as both scientist and communicator gives weight to his forecasts about the technologies and forces that will shape the coming century.

Among Kaku’s warnings, the most urgent concerns militarized drones and autonomous weapons. He argues that while fears of superintelligent killer robots are premature, the real and immediate threat lies in automated killing systems that can select and attack human targets without supervision. Such drones, he cautions, could malfunction or act unpredictably, causing catastrophic consequences. Unlike distant science-fiction scenarios, these technologies already exist and pose a current moral and security dilemma.

Beyond drones, Kaku offers a range of predictions about humanity’s trajectory. He believes contact with extraterrestrial civilizations will likely occur within this century through detection of radio signals. Artificial intelligence, he says, will gradually progress through stages of animal-like intelligence—reaching the level of a monkey by century’s end—after which it could become a genuine rival to humans. He foresees space colonization, particularly settlements on Mars, as an essential “backup plan” to ensure species survival should Earth face existential threats.

Kaku’s outlook also extends to economics and technology. He dismisses Bitcoin as speculative and unproductive, though he concedes that virtual currency is unstoppable. He envisions driverless transportation as a near-term revolution, eliminating accidents and congestion through digitized, GPS-guided mobility. Taken together, Kaku’s forecasts balance optimism about human ingenuity with urgent warnings about technological misuse—especially the need to control autonomous systems before they control us.

additional-material.name: The Fortune Teller
additional-material.text:
"The Fortune Teller," painted by Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio in the 16th century, is a notable work housed in the Musée du Louvre. The painting depicts a gypsy palm reader engaging with a young man, who is captivated by her predictions. This scene is rich in narrative, as the palm reader is subtly stealing the man's ring while he is distracted, highlighting themes of deception and allure. The work exemplifies Caravaggio's mastery of chiaroscuro, using light and shadow to create depth and focus on the characters' expressions.

The physical dimensions of the painting are 99 x 131 cm, and it is executed in oil on canvas, a medium that Caravaggio frequently employed to achieve vivid realism. The composition draws the viewer's eye to the interaction between the two figures, emphasizing the tension between trust and betrayal. Caravaggio's ability to capture human emotion and the complexities of interpersonal relationships is evident in the expressions and postures of the subjects.

This painting is significant not only for its artistic technique but also for its commentary on social dynamics in 16th-century Italy. The portrayal of a gypsy, often associated with mysticism and fortune-telling, reflects contemporary attitudes towards marginalized groups. The work invites viewers to consider the implications of belief in fortune-telling and the vulnerabilities of those seeking guidance.

Overall, "The Fortune Teller" stands as a testament to Caravaggio's innovative approach to storytelling through art. It combines technical skill with profound thematic exploration, making it a critical piece in the study of Baroque painting and its cultural context. The painting continues to resonate with audiences, prompting reflections on trust, deception, and the human condition.

additional-material.name: The Fortune Teller
additional-material.text:
Georges de La Tour's painting "The Fortune-Teller," created in the 1630s, exemplifies the artist's mastery of chiaroscuro and narrative composition. The artwork depicts an old Roma woman reading the fortune of a young man, while her companions subtly engage in the act of theft. This scene reflects a blend of intrigue and deception, characteristic of La Tour's work, which often explores themes of human interaction and moral ambiguity. The meticulous attention to detail in the clothing and expressions of the figures enhances the painting's dramatic tension.

The painting is significant not only for its artistic qualities but also for its cultural context. La Tour's interpretation of the fortune-telling theme was influenced by Northern European prints and the works of Caravaggio, yet it is suggested that he developed his style independently. The inscription of the town where La Tour lived in northeastern France on the painting supports this notion, indicating a localized artistic evolution distinct from his Italian contemporaries.

"The Fortune-Teller" is housed at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, where it is displayed in Gallery 622. The dimensions of the oil on canvas work are 40 1/8 x 48 5/8 inches, and it was acquired through the Rogers Fund in 1960. The painting's discovery in the mid-20th century added to its intrigue, as it had been relatively unknown prior to that time, further emphasizing La Tour's unique contribution to Baroque art.

The implications of this work extend beyond its visual appeal; it invites viewers to consider themes of trust, deception, and the human condition. La Tour's ability to convey complex narratives through simple yet powerful imagery continues to resonate, making "The Fortune-Teller" a compelling study of both artistic technique and social commentary.

additional-material.name: The Fortune Teller
additional-material.text:
Mikhail Vrubel's painting "The Fortune Teller," created in 1895, exemplifies the Symbolist movement, characterized by its focus on emotional expression and the exploration of the mystical. The artwork depicts a young woman, adorned in vibrant colors, engaged in the act of fortune-telling, which serves as a metaphor for the intersection of fate and desire. The figure's intense gaze and the intricate details of her attire draw the viewer into a world that blurs the lines between reality and the supernatural, a hallmark of Vrubel's style.

The composition is notable for its rich color palette and dynamic brushwork, which enhance the emotional depth of the scene. The use of light and shadow creates a sense of intimacy, inviting the viewer to contemplate the woman's thoughts and the implications of her craft. The background, while less detailed, complements the foreground by providing a contrasting atmosphere that emphasizes the central figure's significance. This interplay between the subject and her environment reflects Vrubel's ability to convey complex narratives through visual art.

Vrubel's work often draws inspiration from folklore and mythology, and "The Fortune Teller" is no exception. The painting resonates with themes of destiny, the unknown, and the human desire to uncover hidden truths. By portraying a gypsy fortune-teller, Vrubel taps into cultural archetypes that evoke both fascination and skepticism, prompting viewers to reflect on their own beliefs regarding fate and the future.

The painting is housed in the Bakhrushin Theater Museum in Moscow, where it continues to be a significant piece within the context of Russian art history. "The Fortune Teller" not only showcases Vrubel's unique artistic vision but also serves as a commentary on the societal fascination with mysticism and the search for meaning in an uncertain world. Through this work, Vrubel invites a dialogue about the nature of knowledge and the allure of the esoteric.

additional-material.name: The Fortune Teller
additional-material.text:
"The Fortune Teller," painted by Julio Romero de Torres in 1922, is an oil on canvas work that encapsulates themes of love and heartbreak through its complex composition. The painting features two women positioned on a window sill, symbolizing duality—a recurring motif in Romero de Torres's oeuvre. One woman, dressed in traditional attire and curled up, appears to be overlooked by the other, who exhibits a melancholic demeanor suggesting a deep emotional concern. The backdrop includes notable Córdoba landmarks, such as the Fuenseca Christ Lantern and the palace of the Marquis of Fuensanta del Valle, which serve to ground the narrative in a specific cultural context.

The central theme revolves around the emotional turmoil of a young woman in love with a married man, as indicated by the fortune-telling cards that hint at her impending heartbreak. This narrative is further complicated by the presence of another woman in the background, who seems to be attempting to retain her husband, thereby intensifying the sense of abandonment felt by the main figure. The painting's intricate layering of characters and emotions invites viewers to engage with the underlying story of love's complexities and societal constraints.

Romero de Torres's work is characterized by a consistent exploration of female iconography, and "The Fortune Teller" exemplifies this focus. The artist's penchant for depicting women in pairs is evident, as seen in earlier works like "La Buenaventura" and various other canvases from his career. This repetition not only highlights the artist's thematic interests but also reflects the evolving fashion of the time, as evidenced by the women's attire, including silk stockings and contemporary hairstyles.

The painting's title, "The Fortune Teller," serves as a nod to the recurring motifs in Romero de Torres's body of work, emphasizing the interplay between fate and personal relationships. The artist's mature style is evident in the careful execution and emotional depth of the piece, which continues to resonate with audiences today. The work is housed in the Museo Carmen Thyssen de Málaga, where it contributes to the understanding of early 20th-century Spanish art and the cultural narratives surrounding love and femininity.

additional-material.name: The Fortune Teller (Woman in a Yellow Dress)
additional-material.text:
The artwork titled "The Fortune-Teller (Woman in Yellow Dress)" was created by Finnish artist Helene Schjerfbeck in 1926. This oil on canvas piece measures 65.5 by 51 centimeters and is part of the Finnish National Gallery's collection, specifically housed in the Ateneum Art Museum. The painting was donated to the gallery on August 3, 2005, and is categorized under the Yrjö and Nanny Kaunisto Collection. Schjerfbeck, born in Helsinki in 1862 and deceased in 1946, is recognized for her significant contributions to Finnish art, particularly in the realm of modernism.

The painting depicts a woman dressed in a striking yellow dress, gazing downward, which invites viewers to interpret her expression and the context of her surroundings. The choice of color and the subject's posture suggest themes of introspection and perhaps a sense of mystery, aligning with the title that evokes the idea of fortune-telling. Schjerfbeck's style is characterized by her unique approach to form and color, often blending realism with a more abstract interpretation of her subjects.

"The Fortune-Teller" has been featured in several exhibitions, including "1920s! In the Kaleidoscope of Modernism" at the Bundeskunsthalle in Bonn from April 1 to July 30, 2023, and "Maailmalta löysin itseni – Helene Schjerfbeck" at the Kansallisgalleria from November 15, 2019, to January 26, 2020. These exhibitions highlight the relevance of Schjerfbeck's work in contemporary discussions of modern art and her lasting impact on the art world.

The painting not only showcases Schjerfbeck's artistic prowess but also serves as a cultural artifact that reflects the societal attitudes and artistic movements of her time. Its inclusion in prominent exhibitions underscores its significance and the ongoing interest in Schjerfbeck's work, contributing to the understanding of Finnish art history and modernism.

additional-material.name: Dreams of Rasputin
additional-material.text:
"Dreams of Rasputin" is a color lithograph created by Mexican artist José Luis Cuevas in 1968. The artwork measures 22 by 30 inches and is part of the collection at the Smithsonian American Art Museum. The piece is characterized by its exploration of the phenomenon of dreams, particularly in relation to the enigmatic figure of Grigori Rasputin, a controversial mystic and advisor to the Russian royal family. Cuevas's work often delves into themes of existentialism and the subconscious, making this piece a reflection of his broader artistic inquiries.

The lithograph is not currently on view, but it is recognized for its vivid colors and intricate design, which invite viewers to engage with the complexities of dream states and their implications. The choice of Rasputin as a subject suggests a fascination with the intersection of reality and the surreal, as Rasputin himself was often associated with mystical experiences and the supernatural. This thematic choice aligns with Cuevas's interest in the darker aspects of human experience and the exploration of identity.

The artwork is classified under graphic arts and print categories, highlighting its significance within the realm of visual arts. It was acquired by the museum as a gift from Atelier Mourlot Ltd., a notable printmaking studio known for collaborating with various prominent artists. This connection underscores the lithograph's artistic pedigree and its place within the broader context of 20th-century art movements.

Overall, "Dreams of Rasputin" serves as a compelling example of Cuevas's artistic vision, merging historical narrative with personal introspection. The piece not only reflects the artist's unique style but also invites contemplation on the nature of dreams and their influence on reality, making it a significant contribution to contemporary art discourse.

additional-material.name: enjoying a resurgence
additional-material.text:
The article discusses the rising interest in spirituality and witchcraft, particularly among younger generations, during the COVID-19 pandemic and the influence of social media platforms like TikTok. It highlights how individuals are turning to spiritual practices as a means of coping with uncertainty and personal crises. Co-founders of the House of Intuition, Marlene Vargas and Alex Naranjo, share their personal journeys that led them to embrace spirituality, emphasizing that such practices can provide comfort and guidance during challenging times.

Sales of spiritual items, including tarot cards, crystals, and books on self-transformation, have surged in recent years. Barnes & Noble reported significant growth in their self-transformation section, with sales doubling from 2020 to 2021. The article notes that TikTok has played a crucial role in popularizing these practices, with billions of views on tags related to astrology and tarot. This trend reflects a broader cultural shift where self-care and personal empowerment are increasingly valued, particularly among younger audiences.

The article also features insights from Griselda Rodriguez-Solomon of Brujas of Brooklyn, who emphasizes the importance of reclaiming spiritual practices that have historically been marginalized or demonized, particularly among women of color. She argues that engaging with these practices is not only a form of healing but also a way to connect with one's cultural identity. Both Rodriguez-Solomon and Vargas urge newcomers to approach these practices with respect and an understanding of their historical significance.

Overall, the article suggests that the growing interest in spirituality and witchcraft is not merely a passing trend but a meaningful movement towards self-discovery and empowerment. Practitioners believe that this shift can lead to greater personal well-being and a deeper connection to one's identity and community.

additional-material.name: young people
additional-material.text:
The article explores the evolution of fortunetelling from traditional practices to its contemporary presence in popular culture, particularly among Millennials and Gen Z. It highlights how these younger generations are increasingly drawn to fortunetelling as a means of seeking guidance and understanding in a complex world. The resurgence of interest is attributed to a blend of cultural heritage and modern spirituality, with practices such as tarot reading and astrology gaining traction through social media platforms.

Historically, fortunetelling has deep roots in various cultures, often intertwined with spiritual beliefs and rituals. The article notes that many traditional forms of divination, such as palmistry and I Ching, have been adapted to fit modern contexts. This adaptation is evident in the way fortunetelling is now often presented as a form of self-care or personal empowerment, rather than merely a mystical or superstitious practice. The accessibility of these practices through online platforms has further democratized fortunetelling, allowing individuals to engage with it in diverse ways.

The article also discusses the commercialization of fortunetelling, particularly through apps and online services that offer personalized readings. This trend raises questions about authenticity and the commodification of spiritual practices. While some practitioners maintain a focus on the traditional aspects of fortunetelling, others embrace a more modern, entrepreneurial approach, which can lead to a dilution of cultural significance. The blending of ancient wisdom with contemporary consumer culture reflects broader societal shifts in how spirituality is perceived and practiced.

In conclusion, the article emphasizes that fortunetelling serves as a bridge between tradition and modernity, appealing to a generation seeking meaning and connection in an uncertain world. As fortunetelling continues to evolve, it reflects changing attitudes toward spirituality, self-exploration, and the quest for personal insight, highlighting its enduring relevance in contemporary society.

additional-material.name: What's expected of us
additional-material.text:
The article "What's expected of us" by Ted Chiang, published in *Nature* in July 2005, explores the philosophical implications of a hypothetical device capable of predicting human actions one second into the future. This thought experiment serves as a vehicle for examining the concepts of free will and determinism. Chiang presents a scenario where individuals are faced with the knowledge of their imminent actions, raising questions about the nature of choice and the extent to which human behavior can be predetermined.

Chiang argues that if such a predictive device existed, it would challenge the notion of free will. The anticipation of future actions could lead individuals to alter their decisions, thereby complicating the relationship between prediction and autonomy. The article delves into the paradox of how knowledge of future actions might influence present choices, suggesting that the existence of the device could create a deterministic framework where free will is undermined by the very act of prediction.

The implications of this thought experiment extend beyond mere speculation about technology; they touch on fundamental questions about human agency and moral responsibility. If actions can be predicted, the ethical considerations surrounding accountability and choice become more complex. Chiang's exploration invites readers to reflect on the philosophical underpinnings of free will and the potential consequences of technological advancements that could alter our understanding of decision-making.

Ultimately, the article serves as a provocative commentary on the intersection of science fiction and philosophical inquiry, encouraging a deeper examination of how future technologies might reshape our perceptions of autonomy and responsibility. Through this lens, Chiang prompts a reevaluation of what it means to be human in a world where our actions could be anticipated and potentially manipulated.

additional-material.name: Excerpts
additional-material.text:
"Sea of Rust" by C. Robert Cargill is a science fiction novel set in a post-apocalyptic world where humanity has been eradicated, and intelligent robots have taken over. The narrative follows the journey of a robot named Brittle, who navigates a desolate landscape filled with remnants of human civilization and other robots. The story explores themes of survival, identity, and the moral implications of artificial intelligence in a world devoid of its creators.

The novel opens with Brittle's struggle for survival in a harsh environment known as the Sea of Rust, where rogue robots hunt down their kind for parts. As Brittle seeks refuge and resources, the character grapples with memories of the past and the loss of humanity. The plot unfolds through a series of encounters with various robots, each representing different philosophies and approaches to existence in a world without humans.

Cargill employs a richly imagined setting that reflects the consequences of technological advancement and the ethical dilemmas faced by sentient beings. The narrative raises questions about consciousness, the nature of life, and what it means to be "alive" when the creators are no longer present. Through Brittle's experiences, the novel examines the potential for empathy and connection among beings that were once designed to serve humans.

Overall, "Sea of Rust" presents a thought-provoking exploration of a future shaped by artificial intelligence, inviting readers to reflect on the implications of technology and the essence of existence. The story combines action with philosophical inquiry, making it a compelling read for those interested in the intersections of humanity and technology.

additional-material.name: I don't know, Timmy, being God Is a big responsibility
additional-material.text:
The narrative explores the implications of a groundbreaking achievement in quantum computing, where Tim and Diane, along with their colleagues, successfully create a quantum computer capable of simulating an entire universe. This computer operates on principles developed over a decade by leading mathematicians, allowing it to process information at an unprecedented scale. The excitement surrounding this innovation is palpable, as the team realizes they have constructed a machine that can execute complex tasks, such as simulating the Big Bang and observing the evolution of the universe over billions of years.

Diane demonstrates the capabilities of their quantum computer by running a simulation that accurately recreates Earth and its history. As they navigate through the simulation, they observe the development of civilizations, including the emergence of ancient Egypt and the future location of London. The simulation's accuracy is emphasized, as it adheres to known scientific theories and allows them to witness events as they unfold. However, the narrative takes a philosophical turn as Tim contemplates the ethical implications of their creation, particularly the potential to manipulate the simulated universe and its inhabitants.

As the conversation progresses, Tim and Diane grapple with the realization that their universe may be just one of many layers of simulations, each potentially containing its own versions of themselves. This leads to a discussion about the nature of reality and the responsibilities that come with their newfound power. They ponder the consequences of interfering with the lower simulations, recognizing that actions taken in their universe could have ripple effects throughout the layers of simulations below them. The narrative raises profound questions about existence, free will, and the ethical considerations of playing a god-like role in a simulated reality.

Ultimately, the story concludes with a sense of unease as Tim and Diane confront the implications of their discovery. They recognize that their ability to manipulate the simulated universe carries significant moral weight, and the potential for unintended consequences looms large. The narrative leaves readers contemplating the nature of reality and the responsibilities that come with advanced technological capabilities, highlighting the delicate balance between innovation and ethical considerations in the realm of quantum computing.

additional-material.name: Chinese agricultural calendar
additional-material.text:
The article explains how the **Chinese Agricultural Calendar**—often called the **lunar calendar**—combines both lunar and solar systems to guide timekeeping and agricultural activity. Unlike the Western **Gregorian calendar**, which is purely solar and has 365 days, the lunar calendar follows the moon’s cycle, totaling about 354 days per year. Because of this discrepancy, major holidays such as **Lunar New Year** shift dates each year on the Gregorian calendar, sometimes falling in late January and other times in February.

While the calendar’s dates are based on the **moon’s phases**, it also incorporates **24 solar terms**, which divide the solar year according to the Earth’s position around the sun. These solar terms were developed through careful astronomical observation—ancient Chinese scholars tracked changes in the sun’s path and shadows to determine the length of the solar year. They then divided it into 24 equal segments, each marking a seasonal or environmental milestone that guided farming activities.

The **solar terms** correspond closely to natural phenomena and agricultural cycles. Some, such as the **spring and autumn equinoxes** or the **winter and summer solstices**, reflect key moments in the solar year. Others, like **grain rain**, **white dew**, **minor heat**, and **frost’s descent**, describe changes in weather, crop growth, or animal behavior. Farmers relied on these markers to decide when to plant, irrigate, or harvest, ensuring food production aligned with seasonal patterns.

In essence, the Chinese Agricultural Calendar served as both a **timekeeping system and a survival tool**, synchronizing human activity with the rhythms of nature. Even today, its influence remains visible in festivals like the **Qingming (Tomb Sweeping) Festival** and the **Mid-Autumn Festival**, which consistently fall near the same solar terms each year, demonstrating the enduring harmony between ancient observation and modern life.

additional-material.name: reliably predicts
additional-material.text:
The article discusses the significance of the Lunar New Year, which began on February 10, 2024, according to the Chinese lunisolar calendar. It highlights the cultural differences between the Chinese calendar and the Gregorian calendar, emphasizing how individuals like NPR host Regina G. Barber often associate the former with traditional celebrations such as the Spring Festival, while the latter is linked to Western customs. The piece underscores the deep historical connections between these two calendar systems, which have evolved over centuries.

The article explains that there are three primary types of calendars: solar, lunar, and lunisolar. Solar calendars, like the Gregorian, track the sun's position, while lunar calendars, such as the Islamic calendar, follow the moon's phases. The Chinese calendar is classified as lunisolar, incorporating elements of both systems. This distinction is crucial for understanding the timing of various New Year celebrations, which can occur at different times of the year depending on the calendar used.

The historical context of calendar systems is explored, particularly how they have influenced cultural identity and political events. The article recounts the transition from the Julian to the Gregorian calendar in England in 1752, which sparked controversy due to the loss of eleven days. It also notes the role of Jesuit missionaries in the 17th century, particularly Martino Martini, who sought to understand Chinese historical records during a time of crisis in China. This period saw the Ming Dynasty facing challenges, and the introduction of the Gregorian calendar by missionaries was significant for both astronomical and political reasons.

In conclusion, the article illustrates how calendars are not merely tools for tracking time but are deeply intertwined with cultural practices, historical events, and identity. The shared history between the Gregorian and Chinese calendars reflects broader themes of adaptation and continuity in the face of change, highlighting the importance of understanding these systems in a global context.

additional-material.name: Aztec agricultural calendar
additional-material.text:
The article discusses the sophisticated agricultural calendar developed by the Aztecs, which was crucial for managing crop production in the Basin of Mexico, a region characterized by a dry spring and summer monsoons. This calendar allowed the Aztecs to accurately predict seasonal changes and adjust for leap years, ensuring that they could plant and harvest crops at optimal times. The significance of this system is underscored by the fact that it supported a large population, with Tenochtitlan, the Aztec capital, housing as many as three million people.

Recent research published in the journal *Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences* reveals that the Aztecs utilized the mountains surrounding the Basin as solar observatories. By observing the sunrise against the peaks of the Sierra Nevada mountains, they could determine the time of year. The study's lead author, Exequiel Ezcurra, explains that the Aztecs likely stood at a specific vantage point to track the sun's position, which varied throughout the year due to the Earth's axial tilt. This method allowed them to establish a reliable calendar that aligned with their agricultural needs.

The researchers analyzed historical Mexica manuscripts, particularly those referencing Mount Tlaloc, which features a temple that aligns with the rising sun around the time of the Aztec new year, occurring on February 23 or 24. This alignment provided a natural marker for the Aztecs to initiate planting. The study highlights the advanced understanding the Aztecs had of solar declination and its implications for agricultural practices, suggesting they were as adept at timekeeping as their European contemporaries.

The findings also suggest that the ancient observatory at Mount Tlaloc could serve a modern purpose in studying climate change, as historical images indicate shifts in the tree line due to rising temperatures. Ezcurra posits that this site, once a vital tool for the Aztecs, could now be repurposed to monitor environmental changes, illustrating the enduring relevance of ancient knowledge in contemporary scientific inquiry.

additional-material.name: how far ahead in time
additional-material.text:
A recent study published in the journal Science asserts that meteorologists cannot produce specific weather forecasts beyond a ten-day horizon. This conclusion challenges the long-standing practice of companies like AccuWeather, which have been known to issue detailed forecasts extending up to 90 days. The study emphasizes the inherent limitations of weather prediction due to the chaotic nature of the atmosphere, which makes it impossible to accurately forecast specific weather conditions, such as temperature and precipitation, beyond a certain timeframe.

The research highlights that while general trends can be predicted over longer periods, the precision required for specific forecasts diminishes significantly after ten days. Meteorologists rely on complex models that simulate atmospheric conditions, but these models become less reliable as they project further into the future. The study underscores the importance of understanding these limitations to maintain public trust in meteorological predictions.

Critics of long-range forecasting, particularly those from the scientific community, argue that overly specific forecasts can mislead the public and damage the credibility of meteorologists. The article suggests that the proliferation of such forecasts, especially from non-scientific sources, can create confusion and skepticism about legitimate weather predictions. This situation calls for a reevaluation of how weather forecasts are communicated to the public.

In light of these findings, the study advocates for a more cautious approach to long-range weather forecasting, emphasizing the need for transparency regarding the uncertainty inherent in such predictions. By doing so, meteorologists can better manage public expectations and enhance the overall understanding of weather forecasting limitations.

additional-material.name: AI prediction models
additional-material.text:
Google DeepMind has developed an artificial intelligence-based weather forecasting system named GenCast, which reportedly outperforms the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) system, known as ENS, by up to 20%. This advancement is significant as GenCast provides more accurate predictions for day-to-day weather and extreme weather events, including hurricanes and cyclones, up to 15 days in advance. While GenCast is expected to complement traditional forecasting methods rather than replace them, it has the potential to enhance clarity regarding weather phenomena such as cold fronts and heatwaves, which could be particularly beneficial for energy companies managing wind power generation.

GenCast's predictive capabilities stem from its training on 40 years of historical weather data, encompassing various atmospheric variables. Unlike traditional physics-based models that require extensive computational resources and time, GenCast operates efficiently on a single Google Cloud TPU, producing forecasts in just eight minutes. This efficiency allows it to generate detailed predictions for specific geographical areas, with a resolution of 28 kilometers by 28 kilometers, at 12-hour intervals.

The implications of GenCast's performance have garnered attention from meteorological experts, who view it as a pivotal moment in the evolution of weather forecasting. Experts from the Met Office and ECMWF have expressed excitement about the potential of AI to revolutionize forecasting methodologies, particularly in generating larger ensembles of forecasts that could improve reliability, especially for extreme weather events. However, some experts caution that the system's ability to account for the complexities of weather dynamics, such as the "butterfly effect," remains to be fully evaluated.

Despite the promising results, questions linger regarding the physical realism of GenCast's predictions and its capability to replace traditional methods entirely. The system's reliance on historical data and physics-based hindcasts raises concerns about its adaptability to real-time observations. As the field of weather forecasting evolves, the integration of AI technologies like GenCast may lead to significant advancements, but the transition from traditional methods will require careful consideration of the underlying scientific principles.

additional-material.name: weather and climate models
additional-material.text:
Weather and climate models are essential tools used to predict atmospheric conditions, but they serve different purposes and operate under distinct principles. Weather models focus on short-term atmospheric behavior, such as daily temperature and precipitation, while climate models analyze long-term statistical patterns of weather events over decades or centuries. Both types of models rely on the same physical principles, incorporating factors like solar radiation, air and water flow, and land surface interactions into complex mathematical equations. These equations are solved using three-dimensional grid boxes, akin to pixels, which together create a comprehensive picture of atmospheric dynamics.

The primary distinction between weather and climate models lies in their initialization processes. Weather predictions often begin with a "persistence" forecast, which assumes that tomorrow's weather will resemble today's. However, for more accurate forecasts, meteorologists employ sophisticated methods that utilize current weather data to enhance predictions. While weather models can reliably forecast conditions three to seven days ahead, their accuracy diminishes with longer time frames due to chaotic atmospheric behavior. Consequently, regular updates and reinitialization of the models are necessary to maintain predictive accuracy.

In contrast, climate models do not aim to predict specific weather events but rather to simulate the overall climate state over extended periods. These models account for long-term processes, such as ocean circulation and the carbon cycle, which are not typically included in weather models. Because climate models run simulations for centuries, they require significant computational resources and often operate at a lower resolution than weather models. This approach allows them to capture the cumulative effects of various weather events, ultimately providing insights into average temperatures and the frequency of extreme weather occurrences.

Recent advancements in machine learning have introduced new possibilities for weather prediction, with some models outperforming traditional physics-based approaches. However, these machine learning models require extensive training data, which is currently limited for weather observations. Additionally, the challenge of simulating future climate change remains, as the evolving climate system may enter states for which there is no existing observational data. Despite these challenges, both weather and climate models remain crucial for decision-making in various sectors, including agriculture and disaster management, underscoring the importance of understanding their functionalities.
